bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John D. Long, December 1, 1922

div1.p: Carter sends Long excerpts from a Stegomyia article he is writing that discusses breeding temperatures.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John D. Long, December 1, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
Miss.
Temp. for
slig
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
Dec. 1/22.
Assistant Surgeon General John D. Long,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Long:
div1.p:
Referring to the temperatures and the activity of Stegomyia,
here are some excerpts from what I am now writing:

(B) “Temperature:--The limits of temperature for the functional ac-
tivity--breeding and feeding--of this mosquito are usually given as
from 68° to 102.5° F. The optimum is from 80° to 87° F. The lower
limit is set by that necessary for breeding, as they feed--and pre-
sumably can transmit yellow fever--at a temperature below the in-
ferior limit set for breeding--68 F. The Pasteur Commission work-
ing at Rio, 1903, found 64° F. (18° C.) as the limit of feeding:
Reed's Commission at Quemados (1900) placed it at 62 F. Hanson in
Peru (Lima?) 1922, found them “active and feeding in the evenings”
at 17° C. (62.6 F.) in nature. **************

“It would seem fair then, to put the limits of temperature for
such functional activity as would be of sanitary importance--i. e.
as would continue the existence of yellow fever under ordinary cir-
cumstances--as from about 72° F. to 101°, or 101.5° F.

“Obviously it is implied that these temperatures are those to
which the insects are themselves exposed--which may be very differ-
ent from outside temperatures--and for some time.

(Foot note) LePrince (1922) has recently reported finding this mosquito
producing and feeding in a hotel at Carbondale, Ills., on Jan 19th. and
March 15, 1922. They “were breeding in the writing room in one of the
containers in which flower pots were set.” The out-door temperature at
this place must, at times have been as low as 10° F. or 5° F. during
the winter. Winter breeding of Stegomyia evein in well warmed houses
is, however, altogether exceptional. The writer knows of no similar
case. (End of foot note).

“A drop below 72° F. for even a few days would not eliminate Stego
myiae. **************But it is safe to say that an outside temperature
--say--70 F. to 72 F. long continued, would be incompatible with yell
fever; especially in yellow fever countries in which the houses are ope
and fire--except for cooking--a rarity: Stegomyiae would not breed in
sufficient number to long continue the fever. ******Mosquitoes alread
infected would continue to convey yellow fever as long as they fed, as
has often occurred, among families returning to town at the end of epi-
demics. ******Secondary cases in these returning families must be of
extreme rarity. I do not know that any have been reported. ********

“The imago dies quickly at the freezing point. Flu (1920) states
that at 6° C. (43° F.) none lived 24 hours. At 7° C. to 10° C. (44.6° F
to 50° F.) they are “immediately benumbed, but not past revival until
four days afterwards.”
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General
(On Waiting Orders).
